Engineered a 3-legged rocker–bogie suspension Mars rover to compensate for off-center mass from a side-mounted 5-DOF manipulator.
We built a model Mars Rover During my undergraduate studies, I was a member of the Mars Rover Society—later renamed the Mars Research Station—a student-led engineering team focused on the design and fabrication of an in-house Mars rover for international competitions such as the European Rover Challenge and the Australian Rover Challenge.
Role & Contributions I worked as part of the Mechanical Subsystem, where my primary responsibility was the design, analysis, and fabrication of a customized 6-wheeled rocker–bogie suspension system. This system was engineered to provide high stability during traversal of uneven terrain, slopes, and obstacles. A differential bar mechanism coupled the left and right suspension links, ensuring chassis leveling under asymmetric loading conditions.
Design & Manufacturing Designed a custom rocker–bogie suspension architecture, tailored to accommodate off-center mass introduced by a side-mounted 5-DOF robotic manipulator and onboard analysis station.
Manufactured suspension components using water jet cutting, ensuring dimensional accuracy and structural robustness.
Designed 3D-printed PETG wheels fitted with rubber treads to enhance traction, reduce slippage, and provide passive vibration damping.
Developed the chassis using generative design techniques, followed by finite element analysis (FEA) for structural validation and weight optimization.
Assembled the rover frame using Aluminium 6061 T-slot extrusions, enabling modularity, strength, and ease of maintenance through temporary yet rigid fastener assemblies.
System Optimization & Validation Ensured a low center of gravity and optimized mass distribution to improve balance and rollover resistance on challenging terrain.
Derived suspension kinematic equations to model wheel and motor trajectories about the pivot points, enabling clearance optimization and mitigation of lateral instability.
Validated analytical predictions through full-system FDM prototypes, confirming wheel–motor clearances within 8 mm across the entire suspension travel.
Designed the system to reliably operate under 1.4× the nominal design load, improving robustness and operational safety.
Integrated a passive thermal management concept, where a heat sink transfers heat from onboard electronics into a fluid medium for improved temperature regulation.
Outcome The rover achieved a global rank of 4 at the European Rover Challenge, successfully supporting a 70 kg payload and demonstrating stable traversal over 45° inclined terrain, exceeding baseline mechanical specifications and competition requirements.
summary: Engineered a 3-legged rocker–bogie suspension Mars rover to compensate for off-center mass from a side-mounted 5-DOF manipulator.
title: Model MaRS Rover

Developed a lightweight hand rehabilitation exoskeleton for spasticity using twisted string actuation, achieving comparable functional capability at ~33% of the cost of commercial systems.
Twist-Driven Hand Rehabilitation Spasticity is a velocity-dependent sensorimotor disorder caused by upper motor neuron lesions, commonly resultinging from stroke, and is characterized by involuntary or sustained muscle activation.
This project explores a lightweight, wearable hand rehabilitation system for individuals with spasticity using twisted string actuators (TSAs).
Objective Develop a compact, low-weight hand exoskeleton for spasticity rehabilitation Enable independent finger actuation while maintaining comfort and ergonomics Reduce system cost relative to existing commercial rehabilitation devices System Design & Key Features Suspended hand exoskeleton offering 3 degrees of freedom for ergonomic motion Individual actuators for each finger, allowing independent control Twisted string actuators convert rotational motion into linear displacement Actuator modules require only: External motor connection A single load cell for output force feedback No position or velocity sensors required, reducing electronics and control complexity Actuation Mechanism Twisted string actuation enables: Lightweight and compact architecture High precision and ease of maintenance Vectran / Kevlar strings selected for: High tensile strength Low creep Durability under cyclic loading Designed to deliver: ~45 N peak force ~15 N operating force suitable for spastic rehabilitation Control & Feedback Strategy Linear displacement governed by actuator input parameters Force-based feedback control, relying solely on load cell measurements Eliminates the need for encoders or kinematic sensors Cost & Design Trade-offs Estimated total system cost is approximately 33% of comparable commercial hand rehabilitation devices Cost reduction achieved through: Sensor-minimal architecture Modular actuator design Simplified electronics Trade-off: increased mechanical design complexity compared to commercial alternatives Impact Demonstrates a cost-effective, lightweight rehabilitation solution for spasticity Balances reduced cost with advanced mechanical design Provides a scalable foundation for accessible, wearable hand rehabilitation systems
summary: Developed a lightweight hand rehabilitation exoskeleton for spasticity using twisted string actuation, achieving comparable functional capability at ~33% of the cost of commercial systems.
title: TSA Driven Exoskeletal Glove

Designed and fabricated a 5DOF pick and place manipulator for the Grid Competition hosted by Flipkart.
Low-Cost Vision-Guided Pick-and-Place Manipulator As a team of six, we designed and built a low-cost, spur-gear–driven 5-DOF pick-and-place manipulator equipped with a two-jaw gripper to automate the scanning and delivery of packages. The system was designed to handle packages up to 30 cm × 15 cm in size and 4 kg in weight.
A camera-based vision system was used to determine the position and orientation of each package, enabling the manipulator to grasp and reorient the package so that the labeled surface faced upward for reliable scanning. The design emphasized mechanical simplicity and cost efficiency, while maintaining sufficient dexterity through five degrees of freedom.
My Role (Mechanical Design) One of two mechanical engineers on a six-member interdisciplinary team Led the design of the two-jaw gripper, focusing on secure grasping, load stability, and manufacturability Determined link lengths for the manipulator arm based on the available torque output of the base and intermediate joint motors, ensuring: Safe lifting of 4 kg payloads without motor saturation Acceptable joint torques across the full workspace Balanced reach and mechanical advantage Performed torque-based calculations to relate payload mass, link geometry, and joint loading Developed CAD models and iterated on gripper and linkage designs to satisfy torque, reach, and integration constraints Coordinated closely with controls and vision teams to ensure seamless perception-to-actuation integration
summary: Designed and fabricated a 5DOF pick and place manipulator for the Grid Competition hosted by Flipkart.
title: 5-DOF Pick and Place Manipulator

content:
By prioritizing mobility alongside support, the optimized cervical collar was developed to improve patient comfort, aid rehabilitation, and promote independence in daily activities.
Rethinking the Cervical Collar Cervical collars are widely used to immobilize and support the neck following traumatic injuries and neurological conditions, but most existing designs rely on fixed sizing that fails to accommodate anatomical variability. This often leads to discomfort, improper fit, and reduced patient compliance during prolonged use. This project addresses these limitations through the design of a universally adjustable cervical collar that emphasizes ergonomic fit, improved airflow, and effective occipital support to enhance comfort, rehabilitation, and everyday usability. This project was completed by a team of three as part of the Prototyping and Testing course.
Design Concept The proposed design addresses these limitations through a universally adjustable cervical collar focused on adaptability, comfort, and stability.
The concept draws inspiration from everyday objects such as a tennis ball placed atop a shuttlecock, symbolizing a stable yet adaptable support structure. This analogy informed the development of a scissor-inspired lifting mechanism that enables precise height adjustment to match individual neck anatomy.
Once adjusted, the mechanism can be securely locked in place, allowing the collar to fit a wide range of neck sizes while maintaining structural integrity.
My Contributions (Lead Designer) Led the conceptual design and mechanical architecture of the cervical collar Developed the shuttlecock–tennis ball inspired geometry for adaptive support Designed the scissor-based height adjustment mechanism and locking system Defined ergonomic requirements for neck fit, airflow, and occipital support Produced primary CAD models and coordinated design iterations with the team Guided prototyping decisions based on manufacturability and usability Key Design Features Height Adjustability Scissor-based mechanism enables controlled vertical adjustment Accommodates variations in neck length and anatomy Ensures proper immobilization without excessive pressure Improved Airflow Open structural design promotes ventilation Reduces heat and moisture buildup during extended wear Enhances comfort and long-term usability Occipital Support Provides targeted support to the occipital region Improves cervical spine stabilization Limits excessive head and neck motion during rehabilitation Impact Developed as part of a structured prototyping and testing course, this project demonstrates a patient-centric design approach that improves adaptability and comfort over traditional fixed-size cervical collars. The work highlights the role of mechanical design leadership in translating ergonomic needs into functional medical devices.
summary: By prioritizing mobility alongside support, the optimized cervical collar was developed to improve patient comfort, aid rehabilitation, and promote independence in daily activities.
title: Cervical Collar for Comfort

Designed a full 6-DOF dynamic model for a fin-controlled autonomous underwater vehicle, enabling simulation-driven design and control development.
Formulated the Dynamic Model of an Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV) Developed a physics-based 6-DOF dynamic model for a fin-stabilized, single-thruster AUV to enable simulation-driven design validation and onboard PID control. Initially contributed to mechanical drafting and manufacturing, and was later entrusted with full-system dynamic modeling of the vehicle’s motion.
Project Overview AUV configuration: fin-based control with a single main thruster Objective: Enable forward dynamic simulation Provide a control-oriented model mapping desired motion to actuator commands Role evolved from mechanical drafting to ownership of system-level dynamics modeling Dynamics Modeling Control Structure Inputs
Desired position and orientation in 3D space (6 DOF) Outputs
Individual fin deflection angles Propulsive thrust magnitude Physical Effects Modeled Rigid-body motion in 6 DOF Gravitational and buoyancy forces Hydrodynamic drag and lift Added mass effects due to displaced water acceleration Disturbance forces from underwater currents Fin-induced hydrodynamic forces and moments Thruster-generated propulsion forces Governing Equations The vehicle dynamics are described using a standard marine vehicle formulation:
$$ \dot{\eta} = J(\eta_2) \, V $$$$ M \dot{V} + C(V) V + D V = \tau_{hydr} + \tau_{thrust} $$Where:
\(\eta\) : Earth-fixed position and orientation \(V\) : Body-fixed linear and angular velocities \(M\) : Inertia matrix (rigid-body + added mass) \(C(V)\) : Coriolis and centripetal matrix \(D\) : Hydrodynamic damping matrix \(\tau_{hydr}\) : Fin-generated hydrodynamic forces \(\tau_{thrust}\) : Propeller thrust forces Modeling Pipeline & Tools Geometry & Physical Properties Imported legacy CAD (CATIA → SolidWorks via STEP) Computed mass, center of mass (CoM), and inertia tensor Hydrodynamics Extracted hydrodynamic forces and moments using COMSOL Estimated drag, lift, and added mass coefficients Numerical Implementation Assembled full dynamic model in MATLAB Computed all coefficient matrices for simulation and control Methodology Summary Decomposed inertia matrix:
\(M = M_{RB} + M_A\) Decomposed Coriolis matrix:
\(C(V) = C_{RB}(V) + C_A(V)\) Modeled hydrodynamic damping as velocity-dependent terms
Parameterized fin-generated forces as functions of fin angles and vehicle speed
Modeled thrust as a single-axis force vector:
\(\tau_{thrust} = [f_{thrust}, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0]\) Additional Engineering Contributions 3D Printing Guidelines Led additive manufacturing planning for the AUV outer shell Established process-selection guidelines comparing feasibility, strength, accuracy, and cost Manufacturing Drafting & Quality Control Prepared release-grade part drawings Executed two-stage quality checks verifying geometry, tolerances, and assembly interfaces Miscellaneous Responsibilities Coordinated communication between design and manufacturing teams Selected and validated bonding agents through calculations and expert consultation Established network-based storage for shared design access Set up and maintained the primary computational workstation Generated fastener procurement lists based on structural calculations
summary: Designed a full 6-DOF dynamic model for a fin-controlled autonomous underwater vehicle, enabling simulation-driven design and control development.
title: Internship at HyperHorizon PVT LTD

content:
Uncovered spatial bifurcation and asymmetric flow behavior in acoustically driven inhomogeneous fluids, allowing the creation of advanced acoustofluidic design strategies for efficient particle sorting and droplet patterning.
Introduction to Fluid Mechanics Research By the end of my second undergraduate year, I became interested in the ongoing push toward miniaturization in engineering, where systems are becoming smaller, faster, and more efficient. This led me to explore microscale fluid mechanics, a field rich in interdisciplinary research opportunities and practical applications.
I joined Dr. Karthick Subramani’s Microscale Transport (eMpTy) Laboratory, where I began my research journey in microfluidics and acoustofluidics, focusing on numerical investigations of fluid behavior under acoustic fields.
Acoustic Relocation and Streaming in Two-Inlet Microchannels Numerically investigated two-inlet inhomogeneous fluid configurations subjected to standing acoustic waves Studied the influence of fluid interface location on acoustic stability and flow behavior Demonstrated that configurations with a higher impedance fluid occupying a larger channel width are more acoustically stable Identified regimes where acoustic streaming dominates in near-stable configurations and acoustic relocation dominates in unstable configurations Observed asymmetric flow behavior with streaming suppressed in one half of the channel and active in the other Established interface position as a key parameter governing acoustic relocation and streaming Evolution of Neutral Configurations Under Acoustic Fields Studied miscible inhomogeneous two-inlet flows initially in neutral equilibrium (interface at pressure node) Showed that diffusion-driven impedance variations lead to spatial bifurcation of flow behavior Identified stable regions with suppressed Rayleigh streaming and unstable regions dominated by acoustic relocation Demonstrated relocation of high-impedance fluids to pressure nodes and low-impedance fluids to antinodes Derived practical design guidelines for acoustofluidic particle sorting, emphasizing impedance contrast and channel width ratios Acoustic Patterning of Droplets Using Bessel Beams Numerically investigated mineral oil droplet motion in circular microchannels under standing acoustic waves Showed droplet migration toward pressure nodes due to acoustic radiation forces Identified competing roles of inertial and acoustic forces in determining droplet trajectories Demonstrated controllable droplet patterning through tuning of acoustic frequency, inlet velocity, and energy density Established acoustic-field-driven pattern formation for droplet manipulation Acknowledgement
summary: Uncovered spatial bifurcation and asymmetric flow behavior in acoustically driven inhomogeneous fluids, allowing the creation of advanced acoustofluidic design strategies for efficient particle sorting and droplet patterning.
title: Microscale Transport Laboratory
